title: Problem with Guide solution and challenge solution for Reuse Patterns Using Capture Groups challenge
body:
Below are the current instructions for the [Reuse Patterns Using Capture Groups](https://learn.freecodecamp.org/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/regular-expressions/reuse-patterns-using-capture-groups) challenge.

> Use capture groups in reRegex to match numbers that are repeated only three times in a string, each separated by a space.

Reading through common questions on the forum related to this challenge, there probably should be some modifications to these instructions.  

1. It should made clearer that the numbers should appear consecutively separated by a space vs just repeated three times.  Why?  Because in the following string, the same number is repeated 3 times and the numbers are separated by a space, but they are not consecutive.
```
"42 32 42 42"
```
2. Even if we fix the wording as described above, there is still the issue that the following strings  should match, because all 3 of the "42"s are consecutive and separated by a space.
```
"100 42 42 42"
"42 42 42 100"
"100 42 42 42 100"
"42 42 42 100 100 100"
```
All the above would fail the currently "accepted" regex solutions (both seen below)
```
/^(\d+)\s\1\s\1$/

or

/^(\d+) \1 \1$/
```

title: Define the Head and Body of an HTML Document | Can pass tests without a body tag
body:
**Describe your problem and how to reproduce it:** The request for this problem is: `Edit the markup so there's a head and a body. The head element should only include the title, and the body element should only include the h1 and p.` However, all the tests pass even without a `body` tag, including these two tests specifically checking for it: - There should be only one body element on the page. - The body element should wrap around both the h1 and p elements. Code that will pass: ``` The best page ever

The best page ever

Lorem Ipsum

``` **Add a Link to the page with the problem:** https://learn.freecodecamp.org/responsive-web-design/basic-html-and-html5/define-the-head-and-body-of-an-html-document **Tell us about your browser and operating system:** * Browser Name: Chrome * Browser Version: 73 * Operating System: Windows 10 **If possible, add a screenshot here (you can drag and drop, png, jpg, gif, etc. in this box):** ![page](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8443638/55522349-722a2500-5639-11e9-8120-30e975ed13e1.png)

body:

- [x] My changes do not use shortened URLs or affiliate links.

<!--If your pull request closes a GitHub issue, replace the XXXXX below with the issue number.-->

While reviewing #35746, I noticed that the Array Sort challenge doesn't mention anything about the details of how a regular compare function callback works, when one is provided to `.sort()`. I feel like this information is critical to implementing any sort function, especially if you don't want the default Unicode value based ordering during the sort.

This PR moves the details about the compare function that @RandellDawson added to the Hints section for the challenge, to the challenge itself.

title: Offline Support: Make dependencies from CDN available in client bundle
body:
We want to bundle some of our dependencies like Lato fonts, Bootstrap and MathJax with the client app.

Anything that is being pulled from CDN is not going to be available in an offline no internet environment.

Ref: #35752

title: Need to add full working solutions to 47 challenges in the Front End Libraries section
body:
With a quick search, I found there are currently 47 challenges in the Responsive Web Design section that are missing a full working solution.  I wan to use this issue to help track who wants to work on adding these and when the PRs get merged.

Please make sure to remove the `// solution required` and make sure to surround the solutions using `html` instead of `js` (see below for example).
````
```html
solution code goes here
```
````
Make sure to add full code (original challenge seed plus any changes needed to pass challenge) for all challenges in a section.  Please create a separate PR for each set of section challenges to make the review process faster.  I have listed the sections below with the applicable challenge file paths.  Before creating each PR, please test that all solutions pass by testing them locally using `npm run test:curriculum`.

**Notes:**  
1. Only do the English files, because we can copy the solutions over to the other languages in one PR once all have been added to the English version.
2. Instead of write `Closes #this-issue-number`, just write `Related to issue ` when creating the actual PR.  We will close this issue once all solutions for all sections have been merged.

title: fix(guide): Corrected/Improved Hint and made similar solution to hint for Sort an Array Alphabetically using the sort Method challenge
body:
- [x] I have read [freeCodeCamp's contribution guidelines](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
- [x] My pull request has a descriptive title (not a vague title like `Update index.md`)
- [x] My pull request targets the `master` branch of freeCodeCamp.
- [x] None of my changes are plagiarized from another source without proper attribution.
- [x] All the files I changed are in the same world language (for example: only English changes, or only Chinese changes, etc.)
- [x] My changes do not use shortened URLs or affiliate links.

Many forum users are confused on the **Sort an Array Alphabetically using the sort Method** challenge ever since Chrome made changes to the way the sort method works (now it correctly uses the compareFunction).  I noticed the hint in the Guide on `master` was incorrect, so I fixed it and added some extra verbiage to the hint.  Lastly, I made the example solution have the reverse logic of the hint example.

- [x] My changes do not use shortened URLs or affiliate links.

<!--If your pull request closes a GitHub issue, replace the XXXXX below with the issue number.-->

As discussed in #35729, Travis CI passes bad YAML syntax.  This happens because YAML exceptions are generated asynchronously and not handled, so they do not result in failing tests.  This PR handles these types of errors, then re-throws them, causing the tests to fail informatively.

This PR doesn't fully address that issue, however.  As @raisedadead pointed out, these types of mistakes should be caught during linting.  The exception handling here is just intended as a fail-safe.

title: chore: make local installations even faster
Contradictory Instructions - Quality Assurance and Testing with Chai - Run Functional Tests using a Headless Browser
Travis CI false positives
body:
**Describe the bug**
Certain syntax errors in challenge markdown are incorrectly passed by Travis CI.  [This build](https://travis-ci.com/ojeytonwilliams/freeCodeCamp/builds/106547060) is an example that should fail, but does not.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Put a syntax error into challenge markdown - I tested this by indenting `testString` with 5 spaces instead of 4 in `curriculum/challenges/english/02-javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/es6/use-arrow-functions-to-write-concise-anonymous-functions.english.md`
2. `npm run test`
3. This will throw an error, but the testing never finishes.
4. Push to GitHub and trigger a Travis build.
5. This should not pass, but does.

**Expected behavior**
If the local `npm run test` fails, so should Travis.

While waiting for the builds to finish, I did a little digging.  It looks like the bad YAML causes an exception that stops the tests from starting properly.  I'd be happy to try and sort this out.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Ubuntu 18.10 (Cosmic Cuttlefish)

title: [beta] Challenge instruction drops to a new line mid-sentence
body: **Describe your problem and how to reproduce it:** Go to challenge `Basic JavaScript: Global Scope and Functions`. The instruction's last sentence breaks to a new line mid-sentence. (This issue does not exist in production: https://learn.freecodecamp.org/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/basic-javascript/global-scope-and-functions/ ) **Add a Link to the page with the problem:** https://www.freecodecamp.rocks/learn/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/basic-javascript/global-scope-and-functions **Tell us about your browser and operating system:** * Browser Name: * Browser Version: * Operating System: **If possible, add a screenshot here (you can drag and drop, png, jpg, gif, etc. in this box):**
